hints_html: We need the chain rule for this problem and might need to use it more than once. Can you identify an inner and outer function for \(f(x)\)?
hints_latex:
We need the chain rule for this problem and might need to use it more
than once. Can you identify an inner and outer function for $f(x)$?
hints_raw: We need the chain rule for this problem and might need to use it more than once. Can you identify an inner and outer function for <math>f(x)</math>?
question: 1 (n)
sols_html:
This question requires multiple uses of the chain rule.

\[\begin{aligned} \displaystyle f(x) = \ln(1 + \ln(1 + \ln(x)))\end{aligned}\]

Recognizing that the inner function is \(u = h(x) = 1 + \ln(1 + \ln(x))\) and the outer function is \(g(u) = \ln(u)\), we apply the chain rule and get

\[\begin{aligned} f'(x) &= g'(h(x))\cdot h'(x) \\ &= \frac{1}{1 + \ln(1 + \ln(x))}\cdot h'(x).\end{aligned}\]

Now we need to use the chain rule again to evaluate \(h'(x)\). The function \(h(x)\) has inner function \(v = k(x) = 1 + \ln(x)\) and outer function \(j(v) = 1 + \ln(v)\). Thus, \(h'(x)\) is given by

\[\begin{aligned} h'(x) &= j'(k(x))\cdot k'(x)\\ &= \frac{1}{1 + \ln(x)}\cdot k'(x) \\ &= \frac{1}{1 + \ln(x)}\cdot \frac{1}{x}\end{aligned}\]

Thus putting the pieces together, we write the expression for the derivative of \(f\):

\[\begin{aligned} {\color{blue}f'(x) = \frac{1}{1 + \ln(1 + \ln(x))}\cdot\frac{1}{1 + \ln(x)}\cdot\frac{1}{x} }.\end{aligned}\]
statement_html:
Find the derivative of the function

\[\begin{aligned} \displaystyle{}f(x)=\ln(1+\ln(1+\ln(x))).\end{aligned}\]
statement_raw:
Find the derivative of the function

:<math>
\displaystyle{}f(x)=\ln(1+\ln(1+\ln(x))).
</math>
